content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
How do you know what happens to your money after you spend it?

Most Americans check their bank accounts at least once a week, but many still face surprise fees and overdrafts because they're not tracking their transactions properly.

objectives.description: Various banking tools including ATMs, debit cards, checks, and online banking services
Financial transactions by maintaining accurate records of spending and deposits
Personal financial records with bank statements to catch errors and discrepancies
Common banking fees and strategies to avoid them and protect your money

terms.definition: Written orders instructing your bank to pay a specific amount to a person or organization from your account
terms.example: Writing a $750 rent check to your landlord, who then deposits it into their account

terms.definition: Cards linked directly to your checking account that allow you to make purchases or withdraw cash instantly
terms.example: Using your debit card to pay $45 for groceries, which immediately deducts from your balance

terms.definition: Automated Teller Machines that let you withdraw cash, check balances, deposit money, and transfer funds
terms.example: Withdrawing $100 from an in-network ATM without paying extra fees

terms.definition: Digital platforms that allow you to check balances, transfer funds, pay bills, and manage accounts 24/7
terms.example: Using your bank's app to schedule automatic bill payments and set up balance alerts

paragraphs: Modern banking offers multiple tools to access and manage your money. Each tool has specific advantages depending on the situation.
bulletPoints: Checks ‚Äî Best for rent, large payments requiring paper trail
Debit Cards ‚Äî Convenient for everyday purchases
ATMs ‚Äî Quick cash access when needed

paragraphs: Banking fees can eat away at your money if you're not careful. Understanding these fees is the first step to avoiding them in {{STATE_NAME}}.
bulletPoints: Overdraft Fee ‚Äî Charged when you spend more than your balance ({{AVG_OVERDRAFT_FEE}} average in {{STATE_NAME}})
Monthly Maintenance ‚Äî Regular account fee ({{AVG_MONTHLY_FEE}} average in {{STATE_NAME}})
ATM Fees ‚Äî Out-of-network withdrawal charges ($3‚Äì5 per use)

leftPanel.title: Smart Banking Means Fewer Fees
paragraphs: With a few simple habits, you can eliminate most banking fees and keep more of your hard-earned money.
bulletPoints: Track Your Balance ‚Äî Check your account regularly; set up low balance alerts to warn you before you overspend
Use In-Network ATMs ‚Äî Find your bank's ATM locator on their app to avoid out-of-network fees
Meet Requirements ‚Äî Maintain minimum balances or set up direct deposit; consider credit unions like {{STATE_LOCAL_CREDIT_UNION_NAME}} in {{STATE_NAME}}

leftPanel.title: Balancing Your Account
paragraphs: Reconciliation means comparing your personal records with your bank statement to ensure everything matches.
bulletPoints: Identify any errors or unauthorized charges
Catch bank mistakes that could cost you money
Maintain accurate understanding of your balance
Prevent overdrafts before they happen
Track spending patterns over time

scenario.name: Maria ‚Äî The Organized Tracker
paragraphs: Maria checks her bank account every morning using her mobile app. She set up alerts for any transaction over $20 and keeps a simple spreadsheet tracking her monthly spending. She uses in-network ATMs and maintains the minimum balance to avoid fees.
Maria's proactive approach ensures she never pays overdraft fees and catches errors before they become costly.

scenario.name: James ‚Äî Learning the Hard Way
paragraphs: James never checks his account balance and frequently uses out-of-network ATMs for convenience. Last month he overdrew his account three times and didn't notice an unauthorized $50 charge until his statement arrived 30 days later.
James paid 3√ó {{AVG_OVERDRAFT_FEE}} in overdraft fees plus $24 in ATM fees ‚Äî all avoidable with basic monitoring habits.

content.question:
What banking fees have you or your family experienced, and how could they have been avoided?

Consider: ATM fees, overdraft charges, minimum balance penalties, or monthly maintenance fees. What daily or weekly habits could prevent these fees?

Why is it important to keep track of your daily spending and regularly check your account balance?

What could happen if you don't track your transactions for a month? How would knowing your exact balance change your spending decisions?

main.title: Check Register
main.description: Practice tracking financial transactions by updating a check register based on a sample bank statement. This foundational skill helps you maintain accurate records and avoid overdrafts. Scenario: Use the provided bank statement showing deposits and withdrawals.

steps: Review the Statement ‚Äî Examine the provided bank statement showing deposits and withdrawals
Update the Register ‚Äî Record each transaction with date, description, and amount
